title: 105_hr3860
content: The Act titled "Capital Gains Sunset Act" introduces a 100 percent capital gains deduction under Section 1201 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act introduces a 100 percent capital gains deduction for taxpayers with net capital gains. Estates and trusts calculate the deduction by excluding gains includible by income beneficiaries. The net capital gain is reduced by investment income for tax purposes. Transitional rules apply for certain taxable years. Transitional rules apply for taxable years including January 1, 2002, limiting net capital gains to gains and losses after that date. Pass-thru entities have special rules for determining net capital gains. The determination of gains and losses for pass-thru entities is made at the entity level. A pass-thru entity includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. Additionally, a deduction for long-term capital gains is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. The deduction for long-term capital gains is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code, including striking subsections and paragraphs. Amendments are made to the tax code regarding capital gains and losses, limiting deductions for losses from sales or exchanges of capital assets and disallowing the deduction for capital gains under section 1201. The last sentence of section 453A(c)(3) is also amended. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code, including changes to deductions for capital gains and losses. Section 1201 deduction is now required to be taken into account, and adjustments are made for gain from the sale of capital assets held for more than 1 year. Amendments to the tax code include adjustments for deductions related to capital gains under section 1201. The deduction allowed for trusts is subject to unrelated business income rules. The last sentence of section 643(a)(3) specifies that the capital gains deduction should not be considered. Additionally, section 643(a)(6)(C) clarifies that the capital gains deduction should not be taken into account. Amendments to the tax code include changes to various sections such as 691(c), 801(a), 831(c), and 852(b)(3) regarding deductions and capital gains. Amendments to the tax code involve changes to sections 857(b)(2) and 857(b)(3) regarding deductions and capital gains. Amendments to the tax code include changes to sections 857(b)(3), 871(a)(2), 882(a), and 904(b) regarding deductions, capital gains, and taxable income from sources outside the United States. Amendments to the tax code involve repealing section 1202, amending sections 1374(b) and 1381(b), and making changes to sections 1402(i)(1) and 1445(e) of the Code. Amendments to section 1445 of the tax code involve changing the specified tax rate and removing references to section 1201(a) in various clauses. Additionally, the second sentence of section 7518(g)(6)(A) is modified regarding the imposition of taxes on nonqualified portions. The second sentence of section 607(h)(6)(A) of the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 is amended to exempt nonqualified withdrawals from tax in the capital gain account. The table of sections for part I of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the tax code is also updated. Sec. 1201. Capital gains deduction. Effective Dates: Amendments apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2001. Repeal of section 1(h) applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. Contributions amendment applies to contributions on or after January 1, 2002. Withholding amendment applies to amounts paid after the enactment of this Act. Coordination with prior transition rule for long-term capital gains. Section 1122(h) of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 is excluded when applying section 1201 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
